did.abstract: Professor of constitutional law at the University of Michigan. Papers include correspondence, reports, articles, speeches, photographs, and notebooks, relating to Bates' professional career, with material concerning activities of Ann Arbor National Defense Committee; life and career of Lawrence Maxwell, lawyer and U.S. Solicitor General in the Cleveland administration, funding and building the Michigan Union (1911-1918); Republican politics in the 1930's and 1940's; Franklin D. Roosevelt's attempt to reorganize the Supreme Court in 1937; and campus life at the University of Michigan during the first and second World Wars.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Henry Moore Bates papers, 1886-1950, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Henry Moore Bates (1869 - 1949) had a distinguished thirty-six year career at the University of Michigan as professor and dean of the Law School. Bates was dean for twenty-nine of those years from 1910 until his retirement in 1939. Bates specialized in constitutional law, was widely published, and his influence on legal education was known to be "nation-wide." Bates took an active role in committee and nation-wide activities. Locally, he was involved in the Ann Arbor National Defense Committee and in the building of the Michigan Union on the University of Michigan campus. Nationally, he was called to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee on President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization proposals in 1937. Bates was awarded an honorary degree from the University in 1941.

scopecontent.p: The Henry M. Bates papers include correspondence, reports, articles, speeches, photographs, and notebooks, relating to Bates' professional career, with material concerning activities of Ann Arbor National Defense Committee; life and career of Lawrence Maxwell, lawyer and U.S. Solicitor General in the Cleveland administration, funding and building the Michigan Union (1911-1918); Republican politics in the 1930's and 1940's; Franklin D. Roosevelt's attempt to reorganize the Supreme Court in 1937; and campus life at the University of Michigan during the first and second World Wars.
The papers are organized into Correspondence undated and 1886-1949, Michigan Union Building, 1911-1918; Committee of Nine on Mineral Law, 1927-1929; Miscellaneous Papers; and Photographs.

controlaccess.head: Subjects - Visual Materials:
controlaccess.corpname: Alpha Delta Phi. Peninsular Chapter (University of Michigan)
University of Michigan--Students--Social life and customs--1881-1890.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series is arranged alphabetically. It covers a wide range of topics on legal and political matters and university affairs. A select index to correspondents provides access to some of the more significant correspondents.
The Michigan Union series includes correspondence and other material relating to the planning, funding and construction of the Michigan Union building.

did.unittitle: Committee of Nine on Mineral Law

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous Papers series includes files on a number of legal cases in which Bates was involved, book reviews and articles, papers concerning the Bates memorial service and letters of condolence following Bates' death in 1949.

did.unittitle: Correspondence concerning the selection of the dean of the Law School of the University of Missouri 1939-1940
Papers concerning the Bates memorial services 1949-1950

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series includes portraits; tintype of Bates' father and photographs showing activities as student and as faculty member at the University of Michigan, including photo of deans of the university (1915).
